div.p: The second Part OF THE UN-DECEIVER: Tending to the DISCOVERY Of some PRELATICALL AND ANTINOMIAN ERROVRS; AND THE Clearing of that part of the late COVENANT OF THE THREE KINGDOMS Which concerns Both.
LONDNON, Printed for SAMUEL GELLIBRAND, at the Brasen-Serpent in Pauls Church-yard, 1643.

div.head: THE SECOND PART OF THE Undeceiver: Tending to the Discovery of some Prelaticall and Antinomian Errours, and the clearing of that part of the late Covenant of the three Kingdomes which concernes both.
div.p: THere are two weighty Points commended to our saddest thoughts in these sad times, namely, how to procure first a Reformation, and then a Pacification; Iohn the Baptist was sent in the Spirit of Elias to procure both, Luke 1.17. to turne the hearts of the Fathers towards the Children, (there's a Pacification) and the disobedient to the wisdome of the just, ther's a Reformation. Now there are two sorts of men that oppose a thorow-Reformation, and therefore hinder a Rationall and Christian Pacification. The first sort are carried away with Prelaticall errours, the second sort are carried away with Antinomian errours.
For the first of these, we must consider how they have Idolized the Prelates, and Canonized the Service-book, or (if you will) Canonized the Prelates and Idolized the Service-book.

First for the Prelates, they are by this time known to be Usurpers, and Seducers; now the Rule is, That an Ancient Ʋsurpation is rather a cause of confusion then a ground for prescription: It is certaine that the Primitive Church had the best Discipline, and therefore the restoring of the Primitive Discipline cannot be denied to be a Reformation, and the Reformation of the Church cannot bring desolation upon the State; because Christ will blesse his own Ordinance, and defend his own Discipline by his own power.
Obj. But the King hath sworn to maintaine Prelacy, and the Ministers have sworn to yeeld Canonicall obedience.

Sol. The Law of Nations frames this Answer, In omni Iuramento semper excipitur authoritas Majoris. If you look upon the Church of England as a Nationall Church, which hath all the Rights, Priviledges, and Immunities, (which by the Word of God are conferred upon every true Church) confirmed unto it and settled upon it by the grand Charter of the Kings of England, it is clear and evident, that neither the King nor the Ministers, can be obliged to give any thing to the Prelates (by vertue of an Oath) which is denied unto the Prelates by Gods Word, (there's Authoritas Majoris) and the grand Charter, there's Authoritas Majorum: The words of the great Charter are known, yet I will take the paines to transcribe them, Concessimus Deo & hac praefeuti Chartâ confirmavimus pro nobis & haeredibus nostris in perpetium quòd Ecclesia Anglicana libera sit; & habeat omnia jura sua integra & libertates suas illaesas, &c. vide Mag. Chart. c. 1. This is the Grant of the Kings of England which binds them and their Heires for ever, to preserve all the Rights, Liberties, and Priviledges, (of and in the Church of England) which belong to a free Church, and without which a Church cannot bee a free Church. Now the Church of England cannot be a free Church, if the Prelates be suffered to Lord it over the Ministers and People of God in England, and therefore the King is bound according to the Grand Charter to extirpate Prelacy in England, as hee hath already done in Scotland. We must bee more carefull of Spirituall then Temporall liberty, we are very tender of the personall liberty of every Subject in particular,
but we must be most tender of the liberty of the whole Community of true Protestants as they make one Ecclesiasticall body, or Society, and it doth not lie in the power of any one or more members of that Body, to sweare away the liberty of the whole Society or Church, I say Church, for all the sincere Protestants who doe now enter into this Nationall Covenant are a Nationall Church by vertue of this Covenant; nay, all the Covenanters in all the three Kingdomes are hereby made one Church, though they cannot in person meet collectively in one Congregation, but in regard of their Multitudes are forced to meet distributively in severall Congregations, or else Representatively, in such Guides who are chosen Delegates or Commissioners, to propound, reason, or treat in their behalfe in some Generall Assembly; but that by the way.

We answer farther, if a man have sinned by taking an unlawfull Oath, each Child (that hath learnt his Catechisme) knowes that as soone as hee is convinced of his sinne, he is bound to repent of it, and cannot be engaged in point of conscience to commit a second sinne rather then to repent of his former sinne. It would be strange Divinity to affirme that a man is bound in conscience to sinne, and forbid to repent; whether it is better to goe on in a sinne, or repent of a sinne, wee may safely let them judge, —qui nondum aere lavantur: Hee that hath sworn rashly, must repent deliberately, and not performe his oath wickedly after he is convinced of the sinfulnesse of his oath; for after conviction, it is a greater sinne to keep his oath, then it was before conviction to take the oath, because the first was a rash sinne, and a sinne of ignorance and weaknesse, the second is a deliberate sinne against judgement and conscience.

We need not in these times dispute the point whether the Prelates be of an Antichristian Order, it is sufficient that they are of the Anti-christian Faction, for the Prelates in England are confederate with the Papists in England, Ireland; I might adde Spaine and Italy; and the Prelates have engaged their owne lives and fortunes, the lives and fortunes of all their Hierarchy (as they call it) from the Deane to the Apparitor, nay, the lives and fortunes of all the Prelaticall party, to promote the blacke and bloody Designe of the whole Anti-christian Faction; so that now we are put
upon these straights, that either we must root out Prelacy, or wee cannot root out Popery, and if we do not root out Popery, the Papists will root out Protestantisme, that is, true Christianity; unlesse then we will lose our Religion, and our Civill right freely to exercise our Religion, unlesse we will go over to the Anti-christian party, or which is worse, professe Christ, and serve Anti-christ, we are compelled to protest against the Prelaticall Hierarchy, and to endeavour to take away root and branch. Bishop Hall made too high a claime, and I beleeve he and his party will repent it. Bishops, saith he, must be men of an Ʋpper House, the Peeres of the Church p. 88. Of his divine Right of Episcopacy; or as he stretches Hieromes expression to justifie the tyranny of some Bishops, A Bishop must be as a Generall in an Army, who hath power both to Marshall all the Troopes, and to command the Captaines and Colonels, and to execute Marshall-Law upon Officers. p. 120. Oh you see what the Bishops affect, beware, beware in these bloudy times, lest the Bishops execute Marshall Law upon you, if you will not list your selfe in some of their Troopes, and fight under their Colours, the Black-Crosse displayed in Aceldama a field of blood; Sure such conceits as these of executing Marshall-Law, &c. never entred into Saint Hieroms phantasie, whilest he was awake. What ever this Bishop can take together out of suspected; nay, illegitimate passages fathered upon ancient and famous Authors, all that he urges upon us to assent and subscribe unto, in favour of our Lord-Prelates, wee must beleeve (when wee are at leasure) that Ignatius the Martyr said • , that a Bishop beares the resemblance of God the Father, that hee is superiour to all Principality and Power, and therefore we must be subject to the Bishop as unto the Lord, and to the Priests as to the Apostles. And what proportion is there (saith Bishop Hall) betwixt the respects we owe to God and to man▪ p. 136. But do you heare Lord Prelate, is not this blasphemy? And must a Bishop be acknowledged Superiour to all principality and power (I will give you leave to put in what you have left out) in causes Ecclesiasticall? Is not this a denyall of the Kings Supremacy in causes Ecclesiasticall? Doe you not maintaine that Caesar must obey the Bishop? pag. 142. and is not that your meaning also, p. 143. when you say, Princes must yeeld their necks to the yoke of Christ? &c. You sshould first have proved that the yoke which the Bishops have of
late imposed on Princes, and their people, is the yoke of Christ. Sure I am if Presbyters should use the same speeches to Princes which the Martyred Saints used to their Heathen persecutors, you would have accused them of treason, but it seemes Bishops may use them, and make as bold with Kings, as Ʋalentinian and Traian did with Valens; but Bishops cannot be accused of Treason, because they are in your opinion Superiour to all Principality and Power: or as Jeremie Taylor hath it, The Bishop is in a Peerelesse, an incomparable Authority, and all the whole Diocesse are his Subjects, in Regimine Spirituali: Episcopacy asserted, p. 213. and 214. and the same Master Taylour construes that of Ambrose to the great advantage of the Bishops, Pasce oves meas, unde regendae sacerdotibus contraduntur, m •
rito Rectoribus suis subdi dicuntur, and the sheep are delivered to Bishops, as to Rulers, and are made their Subjects, p. 213. Another man would have said no more, but that the sheepe or people are under their Rectors, for so ordinary Pastours are usually entituled; but these Factors for Prelacy must in stead of feeding the sheepe feed the pride, and excuse the tyranny of the Prelates. I know Doctor Hall, and Ieremy Taylour, pretend to reduce Episcopacy to the Primitive Consistence, but they take some forged testimonies for Primitive testimonies: witnesse those passages of Ignatius formerly mentioned, which are foysted in by Interpolation; witnesse those Canons, which they call the Canons of the Apostles; and witnesse those Apostolicall Constitutions, as they terme them, under the name of Saint Clement, Nay, Master Taylour will adventure as farre as the decretall Epistles, and builds much upon the conformations of Saint Rembert, and Saint Malchus ratified by miracles, Saint Clements Epistle to Saint Iames, translated by Ruffinus; I need say nothing of S. Dionysius, Dorotheus and the rest. Master Taylors Booke is exceedingly cryed up, and it is published by his Majesties command, but truly I see nothing new in it, but what stinkes of Prelaticall Popery; his argument drawne from Episcopall confirmation, consignation, Chrismation, is new, because newly translated out of Popish Authors, and if the Prelaticall party had not been posting towards Rome, he durst not have urged it. The giving of the Holy Ghost by imposition of the Apostles hands, was not, saith Master Taylor, for a Miraculous gift, but an ordinary grace, which ordinary grace is to be still conferred upon the Church; but it
cannot be conferred by Presbyters, therefore it is necessary that there should be Bishops, Prelates, in the Church to conferre this grace of Consigning or Confirmation. The Ministery of the Spirit (which hee saith) is the ordinary Office of giving the Holy Ghost by Imposition of hands, is proper and peculiar to Prelates, read his Episcopacy asserted from p. 28. to 35. He would have new baptized people to be brought to the Bishop, that by Imposition of his hands, they may obtaine the Holy Ghost, and so have a supply made of what was wanting after Baptisme, p. 34.

And he concludes that it was the beliefe of Christendome that the Holy Ghost was by no ordinary Ministery given to faithful people after Baptisme, but onely by Apostolicall or Episcopall Consignation and imposition of hands, in the same 34. page. But it were worth the while, to enquire what this Episcopall Consignation is which the man contends for, it belongs he saith to the ordinary office of Apostleship, an office above Presbyters, but an office to be continued in the Church, and therefore there must be Prelates in the Church, that this so necessary an office may be performed, pag. 35. But you must turn a great many leaves before hee will acquaint you with the secret, and therefore to save you a labour, I will point you to the places you must observe out of him, that there is a three-fold Chrismation; the first is in Baptisme, wherein the Priest doth consigne the forehead of the child with oyntment in the forme of a Crosse (for he tells you, that Consignari is used in Antiquity for any signing with the Crosse or annealing, pa. 206.) and this may, by the leave and favour of the Bishop, be done by a Priest or Presbyter; But this Chrisme or oyntment must be composed and consecrated by the Bishop, and fetcht from the Bishop by the Deacons for the use of all Churches, Chrisma confectum ab Episcopo, pag. 207. Consecratum ab Episcopo, pag. 208. But you must conceive that this Chrisme in the fore-head is a ceremony of Baptisme, and not of Confirmation, for Confirmation is peculiar to the Prelate, pag. 206. And Unction or Chrismation is especially to be used in Confirmation after Baptisme, Sacramentum Chrismatis is the usuall word for Confirmation, pag. 205. Behold a new Sacrament for to make supply of what was wanting in Baptisme, and this supply can be made onely by a Prelaticall Consignation: But lest the glosse upon the Canon Law should be lesse popish then Mr. Taylour, he remembers that the Presbyters
may confirme their Auditors by Confirmation of Faith, but the Prelates onely by Consignation of Chrisme, pag. 203. Well, give us the Confirmation of Faith, and let them take the Consignation of Chrisme, the members of the distinction are surely opposite; it seems then that the Bishops doe confirme men without Confirmation of their Faith, they confirm men in Rite and mystery, the presbyters in Faith and Doctrine by their preaching, pag. 203. Bishops indeed have not used to preach of late, but stay, is not this Confirmation in faith by the Ministery of the Spirit? and is it not a confirmation after Baptisme? why, sure then we need not to have any Bishops to consigne or anneale the Baptized people, and then what is become of this goodly argument? Nay farther, Mr. Taylour confesses, that there was a long dispute between the Greek and Latine Churches, whether persons confirmed by Presbyters should be reconfirmed, pag. 201. I hasten to the third Chrismation, and that is in plaine English, extreame Vnction, which is the annealing of a dying body, and a part of Reconciliation (that's English) which in case of extream necessity is permitted to Presbyters, pag. 206, 207. I beleeve the Church of Christ may enjoy the Ministery of the Spirit by the powerfull preaching, &c. of Presbyters without any one of these three kinds of Chrismation; and therefore the Church may flourish without Prelates.

Behold Mr. Taylours grand Argument lyes speechlesse, but hee hopes to set up the Prelates higher yet, by conferring upon them a Legislative Power, that he may the better establish their Authority of Cognition of causes, and Coertion of persons, whether Lay-men or Clergy-men. The Presbyters, and Clergy, and Laity must obey, (saith Mr. Taylour) therefore the Bishop must govern and give them Lawes, pag. 220. It is, if you will beleeve him, a great part of Christianity to honour and obey the Bishops, pag. 214. It is a fault to remaine in Virginity without the Bishops leave, pag. 216. it seemes Virginity is of Prelaticall Cognizance.

The Presbyters are hardly used, but the Lay-men are much more abused. The Presbyters (hee saith) at the most can but rule in conjunction and assistance, but ever in subordination to the Bishop, the Laity must obey de Integro; (be wholly subject to the Bishop) For that is to keep them in that state, in which God hath placed them, pag. 219. Mr. Taylour cannot deny but that the
Presbyters were termed συνέδρευται και σύμβουλοι τ • ν Επισκόπων, Counsellours and Assessours with the Bishop in Igna • ius his time and yet he would faine reserve the Superio • ity of Iurisdiction to the Bishop, and that Absolutely and Independently of conjunction with the Presbytery, pag. 225. It seemes the Bishops affect an independencie, and therefore are so angry with those Ministers who are termed Independents. He talkes much of Cyprian, but it is clear and evident that Cyprian did not affect that Absolute Independency which Mr. Taylour contends for; it is true that Cyprian being chosen Pr • positus or President of the Presbytery, he took it to heart that they contemned and reviled him whom they had chosen to be their Praepositus, Provo •• or President, and that the Presbyters did challenge the whole Authority and reserve it to themselves; whereas they were not a Presbytery without their President; Quod nunquam omnino sub Antecessoribus factum est, ut cum contumelia & contemptu Pr • posititotum sibi vendicent Presbyteri: These are Cyprians words, and what is there here to prove that a Bishop, Provost, President is Independent upon a Presbytery? Mr. Taylour urges a great many passages out of the Acts of severall Councels; but who over denyed that Bishops did magnifie their owne Authority? or who that is wise would make them Iudges in their owne cause? Truly it is ridiculous to endeavour to prove what was the constant practise of Primitive Christendome out of the Canons of Councels; and to say that provinciall Councels are made Catholike by adoption, and inserting them into the Code of the Catholike Church is to out-speake the Iesuites themselves, and yet these are Mr. Taylours expressions, pag. 234. And I wonder much that Mr. Taylour hath so little forehead to affirme that he can finde no presbyters joyning either in Commission or Fact, in power or exercise with Bishops, but that Censures are appropriated to Bishops. Hee speakes more to the purpose when he saith that the Canons of Councels were confirmed by secular Authority, as appeares in the Imperiall Constitutions, pag. 235. and then from all his allegations he may indeed inferre this conclusion, that prelates were established between three and foure hundred yeares after Christ by secular Authority; but what is this to the point in hand, namely, to shew the constant practise of Primitive Christendome? or to shew that Prelacie is Iure Divino? But because Mr. Taylour hath laid so much weight
upon the ancient Canons (as he calls them) let us, if you will, see what is that Canonicall power conferred upon Bishops. The ancient Canons (saith he) asserting the Bishops power in cognitione causarum speake in most large and comprehensive tearmes, και οἴ τ • θέλωσιν ἐξουσίαν ἔκουσι, They have power to doe what they list, their Power is as large as their Will, pag. 235. Behold an Arbitrary Government, Bishops may doe what they list in the determining of all controversies which concern Church affaires, and judging of all causes that are of Ecclesiasticall cognizance; Now those things which christianity (as it prescinds from the interest of the Commonwealth) hath introduced, all them and all the causes emergent from them, the Bishop is Judge of, such as are causes of Faith, Ministration of Sacraments and Sacramentalls, Subordination of inferiour Clergy to their superiour, censures, Irregularities, Orders Hierarchicall, Rites and ceremonies, Liturgies and publike formes of Prayer, Dispensation of Church-vessels, Ornaments and goods, receiving and disposing of the Patrimony of the Church, and whatsoever is of the same consideration, p. 237. Here's ample power indeed, the Bishop may doe what he pleases in all these and the like matters, for he is in the language of the Iesuites our Superiour, and therefore Mr. Taylour talkes of the Subordination of the Inferiour Clergy to their Superiour, the Bishop must be acknowledged, as Leontius was called, ὁ κανὼν τῆς Εκκλησίας, the Canon or rule of the Church; what need we then to have Canonicall Scripture for our rule? I cannot stand to reckon up all the swelling Titles of the Prelates. All power (saith Mr. Taylour) is derived from Christ, now Kings are Christs Vicars in his Regall power, but Bishops are Christs Vicars in his Sacerdotall and propheticall power, pag. 245. Sure I am he hath not set the Kings Throne very fast on this foundation, for Christ saith, his Kingdome was not of this World, must the King conclude from hence, that he must have no Kingdome in this world? And it is not very sure that Prelates are Christs Vicars in his priestly Office, unlesse they will say that they are priests after the Order of Melchisedech, or that Christ had a changeable and no eternall priesthood, or finally are willing that Prelates should be crucified as Christ was. But though Lord-prelates have such preheminence, yet Mr. Taylour tells us that the Presbyter challenges an higher power, because the Booke of Order of Excommunication in Scotland
assures him, that the Presbytery doth censure men for Murther, Treason, Witch-craft, &c. Nay, they think every action of any man to have in it the malignity of a damnable sinne, pag 250. Nay, they nullifie all Courts and Iudicatories besides their own, Ib. sure he transcribed these two last accusations out of some Iesuite; doth Mr Taylour think any action performed by us in the state of imperfection to be perfectly pure as it comes from us? is there no culpable defect adherent to our best actions? and yet we doe not excommunicate any man for such defects. It may be Mr Taylour hath a farther reach, and thinks some sinnes are not mortall, but in their own nature veniall. I will not expatiate any farther lest I follow him in his digressions, but because he scoffes so much at Presbyterie wee will examine whether there may not be more said for Presbyteriall Government, then he or any other can say against it.

In that Apostolicall List of Church Officers, 1 Tim. 3. and Philip. 1. either Prelates are left out, or preaching Presbyters: but it is cleare and evident that the Apostle doth every where allow of preaching Presbyters, therefore the Prelates are left out. I hope we may urge Philip. 1.1. though I know it was urged by Aerius, the place is cleare to prove that the Church did then consist of Saints, Deacons, and Presbyters, and it is so cleare that Epiphanius who condemned Aerius, was forced to acknowledge that there was no Bishop at the first placed in that and other Churches; St Hierome saith the same, and Saravia confesses that Epiphanius is mistaken more then once in those positions which he layes down instead of answers to the arguments of Aerius, vide Saraviam de divers grad. cap. 22. If a Bishop hath so great a power, as the Prelaticall men say he hath, then we need only prove that in the language of the Apostle a Presbyter and a Bishop are both one, and therefore they are of equall Authority. But this you will say, is the heresie of Aerius. I answer first, that reverend Beza doth defend Aerius against Epiphanius in this point: Secondly, learned Iewel, though a Bishop, defends Aerius against Harding: What saith Bishop Jewel, is it so horrible an heresie to say, that by the Scriptures of God, a Bishop and a Priest (or Presbyter) are all one? Thirdly, Bishop Jewel cites Chrysostome, Hierome, Augustine, Ambrose, and saith, these, and many more holy Fathers together with
St. Paul the Apostle for thus saying, must by Master Harding's advice, be condemned for Heretiks. Iewels Def. Apolog. part. 2. pag. 202. Medina addes Primasius, Oecumenius, Sedulius, Theodoret, and Theophylact. Medin l. 1. de sacrorum hominum origine & continentia, cap. 5. Chysostome, considering that place, Philip. 1.1. saith there were not many Bishops in one City, ἀλλὰ τοὺς πρεσβυτέρους, he called the Presbyters, Bishops: Some cite that of St Hierome, to put a difference between Bishops and Presbyters, Quid enim facit exceptâ ordinatione Episcopus quod Presbyter non faciat? But these men must not stand to this rule, unlesse they will lose their Jurisdiction, whilest they contend for Ordination. Besides, this Reservation was a meer Usurpation, for the Presbyters did ordain by Imposition of hands in the time of the Apostle, 1 Tim. 4.14. By the hands of the Presbytery; Beza observes that some would faine turne πρεσβυτ • ριον into 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 πιοκοπεῖον, nay the hands of the Presbytery into the hands of the Prelate, for the Prelate challenges sole Ordination. Mr. Taylor stands much upon Cyprians authority in this point; Now what Cyprian meant by Presbytery is so cleare in his third Book, Epist. 11. that Saravia confesses Cyprian understood πρεβυτ • ριον to be an Assembly of Presbyters; Fateor Cyprianum Presbyterii voce significass • , Confessum Presbyterorum, vide Sarav. de grad. Ministr. cap. 22. pag. 213. Aerius then was unjustly condemned for saying that Presbyters might ordaine; this place of Timothy in the judgement of Cyprian and many Ancients more, proves that Presbyters may ordaine: Besides, we have another instance for it in the Church of Antioch, there were certain Prophets and Teachers, who laid their hands upon Saul and Barnabas, and separated them to the work of the Ministery whereunto God called them, & they did ordain Saul and Barnabas by the command of the Holy Ghost, Act. 13.1.2.3. who dares deny that this Ordination was complete? and yet there was no Apostle nor Prelate present at this Ordination: And what are the Ministers in the Reformed Churches (where there are no Prelates) no Ministers, because they are ordained without a Prelate? The Canon Law which our Prelates would faine have established, doth permit an Abbat to Ordaine if he be a Presbyter, that's all the Law requires, dist. 69. c. Quoniam, (let them leave citing the Decretall Epistles, if they will not admit of that Canon Law) Abbati manuum impositio conceditur
dum constet illum esse Presbyterum: But enough of that, I passe to Iurisdicton, and here wee shall have our Prelaticall men citing the Decretall Epistles thick and threefold, but Duarenus de Benef. Eccles. in Prooemio observes that most of the Decretall Epistles which concerne Iurisdiction were written to English Prelates, and therefore they are but so many Catholike complements, not Dogmaticall Resolutions, as Mr Taylor would have them: But you'l say they cite many Fathers in this argument; First, we know that many Fathers have erred in matters of faith, and it is more likely they should erre in matters of Fact, because we doe rely upon humane testimony (which is very deceitfull) for matter of Fact. If any one that is reverenced for Antiquity and Piety hath been too credulous, and hath taken up some relations upon trust without due examination, that one man may deceive an hundred, and then if we will reckon right, the hundred testimonies of succeeding Writers is virtually and in a rationall account, but the Testimony of that one man, upon whose credit all their Relations doe depend. Secondly, it is well known that when the Fathers ar • in their Rhetoricall veine, they use many Hyperbole's which will not hold weight without a graine or two of favourable allowance. I remember Hieromes excuse, Rhetoricati sumus, & in modum declamatorium paululum lusimus, Hieronym. adv. Helvidium—ludicious Rivet in his tract de Patrum Authoritate pag. 67. passes this grave censure, Rhetoricantur interdum Patres vehementius vel in exhortationibus, vel in Favorem aliorum; if they are apt to over-lash in favour of others, certainly they are most apt to exceed in favour of themselves, or at least them of their own ranke and order. Thirdly, the Fathers seldome entred into a controversie, but they ranne too farre from their Adversary, and left the truth in the middle between them and their Adversary. Now the Fathers who lived in the time of Aerius and since, have in opposition to Aerius extolled Bishops more highly then they ought. Fourthly, that of learned Casaubon is very considerable, the Fathers handle some things διδακτικῶς, and some ὀικονο ••… ως, dum proposito suo serviunt vide Casaub. Annot. ad Epist. G. Nyss. ad Amb & Bas. pag. 88. & 89. Now that some of the Fathers did proposito suo inservire, in handling the cause of Bishops, is out of doubt, and others might be easily drawn into the same dissimulation, as good Barnabas once was, Galat. 2.13. And yet I reverence
Antiquity as highly as the most reverend Fathers desire mee to reverence it; Concerning the Catologue of Bishops, see Augustines Epistle, 15 •
ad Generosum; Give me leave to begin with Scripture, and I will sh • w enough out of Antiquity in the close. The Prelaticall men talke much of the Angels in the Revelation, much might be said, but I think this sufficient, the Angell of Ephesus was no Prelate, for all the Presbyters of Ephesus are stiled Bishops, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is the word, and had power of Government given them by the Holy Ghost, if 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 import Government, as the Prelaticall men say it doth, read Act. 20.28. St Hierom proves from this place and three more, that a Bishop and a Presbyter are the same in name and power. When St Peter speaks of that ordinary power in which the Ministers of the Gospel succeed the Apostles, he calls himselfe a Presbyter, and exhorts the Presbyters in high language, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , 1 Pet. 5.1.2. and he would not have them 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , v. • . they might have replyed, had there been any Prelates over them in those dayes, Alas, alas, the Prelates are more likely to Lord it over us and the people, give this counsell to the Prelates, they stand in more need of it.

I wonder that men that have been bred in an University should explode and scoffe at a Collegiate Government by a Colledge of Pastours and a President. Againe, I admire that men should fancie that to erect a Presbytery, is to set up a Government which is more Prelaticall then the Prelacy it selfe; for in a Presbytery there is a Priority of Order in the President to avoid confusion, but no Prelaticall Authority to avoid Tyranny, there is no chaire for Diotrephes there. Finally, wee utterly disavow the maintaining of the Independency of a Presbyteriall Church, because we maintaine the use of Synods to be lawfull and necessary, nor doe wee maintain an Independancy of Synods, for the word is their Rule. It is clear and evident by the light of nature, that the part must be in subjection to those who command the whole, all the Members of this Congregation must be subject to the Guides, Governours, & Overseers of this Congregation, & all the Members of this & the Sister-Congregations are subject to the Presbytery, many Presbyteries subject to a Provinciall Assembly, & all the Provinces of the Nation subject to a Nationall Synod, and the Synod subject to the holy Ghost speaking in the word; is not here order, equity, decency? Why do men then
talk of Anarchy, or dream of a popular Government by the many-headed multitude, as if all should runne into confusion, and there should be an absolute Parity, and no Order, or decency at all if Prelacy be extirpated? Away with such vaine conceits, it is evident by what hath been said, that distances will be observed, secundum sub & supra, still; But the great objection is that Prelacy was at first instituted to suppresse Schismes, and therefore if once Prelacy be extirpated, all manner of Sects and Schismes will arise in the Church: I answer, wee know by sad experience, that the Prelates have been the Ring-leaders of an Antichristian Schisme: and we know by good experience, that the Church and Kingdome of Scotland is more firmly united under the Presbyteriall Government, then England hath been under the Prelaticall; no sooner doth a Sect or a Schismatique peep out in Scotland, but presently they are nipt by the Presbytery: And if Prelacy was first invented and Bishops preferred to hinder Schisme, surely since Prelates are become the greatest Schismatiques, Incendiaries, Prelacy may be abolished (since nothing else will serve the turn) that the Schism which the Prelates themselves have made & strengthned, may be timely quelled. The power of the Keyes in the hand of a Presbytery or Synod is sufficient to quell both Hereticks and Schismatiques: if a Schisme hath rent a Province or a Nation to pieces, that Province and Nation is bound by the Word of God, the Dictates of sound reason and Christian prudence to stand to the Decrees of a Provintiall or Nationall Synod, so farre forth as these Decrees are agreeable to the Word of God, for so farre and no farther doe they bind. Let Mr Taylor consider that of St Cyprian in his third Book and 19th Epistle, and then hee will confesse with Cyprian, that one Prelate is not sufficient to cure a Provinciall Schisme: Quae res cùm omnium nostrum consilium & sententiam spectet, praejudicare ego, & solùm mihi rem communem vendicate non audeo. And let him construe that of Augustine, Peregrinus Presbyter & Seniores Ecclesiae Musticanae regionis, &c. lib. 3. contra Cresconium, cap. 56. Or that of Tertullian, Cum Presbyterii ordine praesident probati qui{que} Seniores honorem istum non pretio sed testimonio adepti. Apolog cap. 39. There is a twofold θεραπεία, or Ministry, saith Clemens Alexandrinus, βελτιωτικὴ and ύπηρετικὴ: the first he saith belongs to Presbyters, the second to Deacons; now βελτιωτικὴ, being opposed to ύπηρετικὴ, must necessarily
imply an Authoritative jurisdiction: he saith nothing of a third kind of Ministery; this θεραπεία βελτιωτικὴ was to better the people, not onely by perswasion, but by jurisdiction, for he saith the Deacons were to attend upon the Presbyters, as children upon their Parents, as ordinary men upon Governours. Vide Clem Alexand. Stromat. l. 7. non procul ab initio p 700. Bishop Hall acknowledges that it doth appeare by the observations of Iustellus, and the two learned Casaubons, that there were Seniores Ecclesiastici in the Church of old, and he is forced to confesse that they were not onely Seniores Populi, as Magistrates or Aldermen of Incorporate Townes and Cities, but Seniores Ecclesiae, or Ecclesiastici; and his conceit is ridiculous to dream that such men so renowned were but Church-wardens, he is glad to adde, or Vestry-men at the highest, & so doth in effect grant the whole question concerning Vestry-Elders, read his Reply to Smectymnuus, pag. 146. What will they say to Cyprians distinction betweene Presbyters and Seniors, when he complaines that the Presbyters were too supercilious, taking upon them to doe so much absque consensu Seniorum? I beleeve it will trouble them to answer that question: but they will be more troubled to answer all those Ancient Records which are pressed home by that learned Antiquary Salmasius. I will not enter into that dispute, whether there be a twofold power of the Keyes, potestas concionalis, and potestas Disciplinaria? or whether it be a Pastorall Act to define or determine any thing in Synods and Councels? or whether there be not a difference betweene Pastorall teaching, and Synodicall teaching? whether a Lay-man being Elected a Commissioner to propound, Reason, and Vote in a Synod, in the behalfe of some Congregation, be not a kind of Ecclesiasticall person, in regard of that Office whereunto he is elected and deputed? and finally, whether if a wholesome constitution should be carryed and decreed by the Vote of such a person, helping to make the major part in a Synod, that wholesome Decree doth not bind the people Ecclesiastically in regard of the Authority of them who composed it, as well as Materially, or rather Morally, because the matter of the Decree is agreeable to the Word of God? I must wave these questions and divers others, & passe to the next Prelaticall errour, Their Canonizing or Idolizing of that Service-booke, which the most judicious Divines of the Reformed Churches have ever looked upon as a Pageant
tricked up with tolerable, or (as others) intolerable fooleries, a Masse of Superstition, a Magazine of Ceremonies, the lazy Church-mans Pillow, the blind-Church-maens Spectacles, the lame Church-mans Crutches, and the Common peoples Idol. Nay, some Masse mongers amongst us to testifie their compliance with Rome, have not been afraid to speake out in the reigne of Canterbury, and call it Masse in English, witnesse Cozens, • ecklington, Mountague▪
• nd others. I need say nothing of the letter o • Pope Pius
•• e 4. for the • onfirmation of the Service booke, you may see enough in Br • stowes Motives or Carriers Considerations; Nor need I take notice of the Letter of King Edward the 6. to the Papists of Cornwall and Devonshire, written by the advice of his • ouncell; these things have beene largely insisted on by others. But I would fain have any man prove that when men began to call upon the Name of the Lord at the first in the dayes of Enos, Gen. 4.26. that then they had a Set-forme imposed upon them; Now certainly the Spirit of Supplication since the Ascension of the Lord Iesus is more plentifully powred forth upon the Church, & therfore if men be forced • o read a Dead-form, and pray by Booke in these dayes of light and glory, there will sad effects and consequences follow upon such a rigorous Imposition & constraint. It is evident by lamentable experience that divers Ministers of happy parts and excellent gifts by the use of this Dead-forme in the Service-Booke, have beene utterly disabled to pray after a Spirituall manner upon solemne, but unexpected occasions; their parts have beene dryed up, and withered, their gifts blasted, their spirit straitned in such a fearefull manner, as may well deter any man from tying himselfe to a Service-Booke, and neglecting those parts and gifts which God hath out of his free bounty bestowed upon him, lest God punish his neglect and unthankfulnesse, after such a remarkeable manner as may make him an example to all posterity. I presume no man will defend that order in the Common Prayer Booke, for the reading of Apocrypha, and omitting divers parts of Canonicall Scripture; it is a sinne that cryes to Heaven for vengeance upon this Nation, that wee have by such a solemn Order preferred the Apocrypha before the Word of God, as if the inventions and (to say truth) the fooleries of men did tend ••• e to edification then the Scriptures, which were written by the Divin • inspiration of the Holy Ghost. Nor is it possible to excuse
many ridiculous passages in that Translation of Scripture which is retained in the Common-Prayer. Book; witnesse that Passage, And Easter a Feast of the Iewes was nigh; and that of Galat.
• .20. where they make zeale a fruit of the flesh, which perchance is the reason, why the Prelaticall men have been so constantly obeyed by the common people when they have inveighed against zeale; sure the common people have taken this Translation for the Word of God, and looked upon zeale as a fruit of the flesh which would pollute and defile them, and therefore there is so little zeale in those Countreys where they have had no other service, then what is contained in this Service Book. Moreover, they have in the Epistle for the Sunday after Christmasse-day falsly, if not blasphemously and Heretically translated Galath. 4.5. That we through Election might receive the Adoption that belongs to naturall Sonnes, an arrant contradiction, and as we use to call it, a Bull, for no naturall Sonne can be said to be adopted, nor is any adopted sonne a naturall sonne; Nothing but Generation can make a man a naturall son. Now none but the Lord • esus is the naturall Sonne of God. The true Translation is, That we might receive the Adoption of Sonnes. Now the adopted Sonnes of God are in that very verse opposed to his naturall Sonne spoken of in the former verse, God hath sent forth his own Sonne, vers. 4. that is, his naturall Sonne; but enough of that; And they might have followed a better Translation of Galat. 5.19.20. which runnes thus, The works of the flesh are manifest, &c.—hatred, variance, emulations, wrath, strife, seditions, heresies; and not as they read in their Epistle for the 14th Sunday after Trinity▪ The deeds of the flesh are manifest, &c. Hatred, variance, zeale, wrath, strife, seditions, Sects, in stead of Heresies; our Arminians tell us, that Hereticks are pious and innocent men, and therefore not punishable. They follow the Masse book in Translating Luke 1.28. Haile thou that art full of grace, in stead of Haile thou that art highly favoured: and so Luk. 1.48. Hee hath regarded the lowlinesse, in stead of the low estate; as if the blessed Virgin had merited to be the Mother of God by her humility and lowlinesse of minde; the Word in the Originall is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and not 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . I cannot omit their Translation of Psalm. 105.28. They were not obedient to his word, but the Holy Ghost declares the contrary, and saith, they rebelled not against his word. In the Gospel
for St Luke's day, they Translate Luk. 10.1. The Lord appointed other seventy and two, whereas the holy Ghost saith the Lord appointed other seventy, th • y take the boldnesse to adde two more then the holy Ghost sp •• ks of. Now this fault is the more inexcusable because there is a purer Translation of the Scriptures, published by Authority, and yet the Prelates have still retained these grosse corruptions.

I wonder that they should all this while connive at such an intolerable disagreement between the Translations, I will give but one instance more, in the Psalmes in the Common-Prayer-Book, Psal. 58.8. we read, so let indignation vex him • ven as a thing that is raw, in stead of these words, He shall take them away as with a whi • lwind both living and in his wrath, as you may see by comparing it with our new Translation; but observe that it is the ninth verse in the New-Translation. Besides, there is no sense in that Liturgicall Translation, Or ever your pots be made hot with thorns, so let indignation vex him even as a thing that is raw. The common people (hearing that there is only a directory for Worship intended, as appears by the late Covenant) conceive that they shall be deprived of whatsoever is in the Common-Prayer-Book; but they should consider that the Common-Prayer-Book containes things of very different natures, Creeds, Commandments, Psalms, Prayers, &c. Now the Parliament never intends to take away the Psalmes, Commandments, or those parts of Scripture which are called Epistles and Gospels, but the people shall enjoy these in a more faithfull Translation in their Bibles, and have them familiarly expounded and powerfully applyed to their consciences by able and conscionable Ministers; for the Parliament daily seeks for such to instruct the people, but the Prelates would never allow of any such Translation in the Service-Book, or such an exercise as the expounding of the Commandments, &c. They counted that as bad as Preaching. Nay, the Parliament intends not to take away the Creeds, for though they be not parts of Scripture, yet because the sum and substance of them was collected out of Scripture, the Creeds shall be retained, and those obscure phrases which might occasion a mistake, namely, the Descent into Hell, &c. shall be explained agreeable to the Word of God, and the Analogy of faith. Moreover, we must put a great deale of difference between the Lords
Prayer, and Prayers composed by man; The Parliament will not take away the Lords prayer, nor forbid the use of it; and if some prayers (composed by men subject to mistakes) which are many of them rather good wishes then Prayers, be omitted, there will be no great want of them, considering first, that though there are many Christian prayers, in regard of the expressions, yet the whole body of them hath ever by the Prelaticall party been designed to an Antichristian use, namely to nourish an ignorant lazy and ambitious Clergy, for the Non-Residents by this meanes doe only pay for a Reading Curate, and are allowed to bee Non-Residents: Secondly, that they were composed in times of ignorance, for the help of Ministers almost as ignorant as the common people: Thirdly, that God hath now furnished his Church with men of excellent parts and gifts, Who are able to pray as well as preach upon all occasions, and it were as great pity to hinder the exercise of these mens gifts by making a Prayer for them, as by making a Sermon for them; the one is as great a shame to them and damp to their Spirits as the other: and the State may as well forbid them to preach a Sermon of their own studying, and tye them to read Homilies, as to forbid them to use a prayer of their own composing, and command them who are truly Iudicious, Practically holy and Experimentally Devout, to read a prayer out of a book, more like a Schoole-Boy then Reverend Pastours of the Church of Christ. Nay, if an ingenious School-boy would bee ashamed to read a Declamation composed by another, when he is called to perform that exercise, sure a Minister of Christ will bee more ashamed to have a prayer made for him by Bishops or Arch-Bishops, when the Arch-Shepheard & Bishop of his Soul hath left him, A pattern of prayer, a rule of prayer, and a Spirit of prayer to help his infirmities, and blesse him with abilities for this great duty of prayer. It concernes Ministers in this point to imitate the Apostles, Act. 6.4. to give themselves continually to prayer, as well as to the Ministry of the Word; 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 is the full expression of the holy Ghost in that place. Can the Prelates teach us to pray better then the holy Ghost? Now the holy Ghost teacheth us both what and how to pray; We know not what to pray for, as wee ought, we are ignorant of matter and manner; the holy Ghost helps our infirmities in both, Rom. 8.26. And if the holy Ghost doth afford such assistance to ordinary Christians, sure much more to
Pastours whom he hath commanded to give themselves to prayer, and to whom he hath given variety of Pastorall gifts that they may discharge all Pastorall duties. Christ hath sent some Pastours, some Teachers for the perfecting of the Saints, for the work of the Ministry, that the Saints may be no more Children, Ephes. 4.11.12.14. Now doth God send Pastours, send them for the work of the Ministry? and doth hee not inable them for the work of the Ministry? or is not prayer a work of the Ministry? Is the Pastour sent by God to perfect the Saints, and will not God perfect the Pastour for the performance of pastorall duties, that the Saints may be perfected? Hath God sent Pastours to instruct the Saints that the Saints may no longer be children, and must the Pastours still remaine children, and bee set to read prayers out of book, like very children? Away with such ridiculous and vaine conceites. But if the common people who have been nursed up in ignorance and superstition, will not part with their old customes, and are resolved to keep this Service-Book, let it bee then considered whether the Queen and the Prelates and the Romane Catholique-subjects, (I must not say Rebels, English and Irish, now after the Irish Pacification, whom the Queen and the Bishops have stirred up) are likely to pleasure the people in this particular? It is well known that the great Prelates doe not like this Common-Prayer-Book, they composed one a great deale worse, and sent it into Scotland; I am perswaded the most ignorant people would lose their dearest bloud rather then receive that Common-Prayer-Book which was sent into Scotland, and they must expect that or a worse, if the Bishops may have their will. And sure if the Queen may prevaile with the Bishops, or the Jesuits with the Queen, the common people shall not have, no not that Common-Prayer-Book (which was sent into Scotland) in English; they must have it, or the very Masse, in Latine, that's plaine English; nay, believe it good people, the Queen and her party are likely to take away not only this Common-Prayer-Book, but even the Bible also, and not leave you so much as the Word of God in English. Oh, but if the Common-Prayer-Booke bee taken away, what Religion shall wee have? Why sure, that Religion, which Christ and his Apostles had before there was any Common-Prayer-Book, for they left us none, and Christians had none for the first 300 yeeres; Your Religion is many hundred
yeeres more ancient then this Common-Prayer-Book, the Primitive Religion is the old Religion. Bee content then with a Directory, and if any man pray non-sense, blasphemy, &c. hee shall bee punished for not observing the pious and prudent directions given.

But though this Forme prescribed in the Service-Book be a Dead Form, yet for their sakes who composed it, let it be honourably buried. I need say no more of the Prelaticall errours; all that they have to plead now, is the Law of the Land, and that is much insisted on by some. First, I wonder they should now come to plead Ius humanum, who have bragged so much that they were Iure Divino, and given out that they would not hold their Bishopricks an houre, if they could not prove that they held them by Divine Right. Secondly, This case being propounded to a great Lawyer and Antiquary in th •• Kingdome, it was resolved by him, That the Hierarchy abiured in this Covenant, was never established by Law in England. Thirdly, though there w • s a Prelacy forged by the Canon-Law, and that Law too much received in time of Popery, yet by the submission of the Clergy in the 25th of Henry the 8th, that Law was clearely abolished, and consequently all Arch-Bishops, Bishops, Arch-Deacons, &c. depending upon the Authority, and drawn from the grounds and rules of the Canon-Law, are abolished. Fourthly, the Bishops have had power to exercise Iurisdiction in England by vertue of the High-Commission, but the Act passed against the exercise of that power in the High-Commission, hath made their Commission void, and their Authority of none effect. Fiftly, that Statute of proviso's which they brag of, wil not advantage them, for by that it appeares that they were set up to informe the people of the Law of God▪ and to make Hospitalities, and Almes, and other works of Charity, and this they may do still according to their ability. This case being propounded to a great Statesman, whether the Prelates, who have engaged themselves in this Antichristian warre, should not have a legall tryall? His answer was, We give Law to an Hare, but we give a polt to a polt-cat. Dr Hall (as hath been shewn) saith the Bishops might give Marshall law: and now it seemes they must suffer Marshall law. Sure a Prelate in Armes, and a Prelate Confederate with the Irish Rebels of the Spanish faction,
may thank himselfe if he get a polt, and will deserve but part of Cardinall Richelieu his Epitaph, if he get a victory.

So much for Prelates; Even so let all thine enemies perish O Lord, but let them that love thee, bee as the Sunne when he goeth forth in his might, that England and Ireland, and all the Reformed Churches may have rest, Amen, Amen. Judg. 5.31.

But a word or two at this time to the Antinomians; for certainly they have very little reason to cry out against this Covenant, unlesse they are offended with the Gospel, as well as with the Law; for the sinnes specified in this Covenant are sinnes directly against the Gospel, and will they deny that we are too humbled for sinnes against the Gospel also? who is there who hath not good cause to cry guilty, and acknowledge that he hath not as he ought, valued the inestimable benefit of the Gospel? Oh! the under-valuing of the Gospel of the Lord Iesus is a crying sinne, our sinne will cry, if we doe not. O let us loath our selves because wee have not laboured for the purity and power of the Gospel, that wee have not endeavoured to receive Christ in our hearts, nor to walk worthy of him in our lives: These, these, are sinning sinnes, the causes of other sinnes and transgressions so much abounding amongst us. Doe we not in the close of the Covenant beseech the Lord to strengthen us by his holy Spirit, that we may be enabled to keep this Covenant? as that a Legall prayer? O but we swear to preserve the Discipline and Government in the Church of Scotland; True, but we sweare only to preserve it against our common enemies. and sure the Antinomians will grant that the Discipline of the Church of Scotland is farre better then English Prelacy, or down right Popery. But are there no defects in that Discipline? admit there be, yet neverthelesse so farre
forth as they have attained, let it bee preserved: If the Moone have spots, must it bee plucked from the Firmament? and if a Church have defects, must wee suffer it to be ruined by an Antichristian faction, which seeks the ruine of all Churches which desire a thorow-Reformation. Finally, the Church of Scotland is willing to see her defects, if you can shew them, they will give you thanks, and reforme according to their Covenant; they desire that all three Kingdomes may bee brought to the neerest conjunction and uniformity in Religion and Forme of Church Government according to the Word of God. It is confessed on all sides, that as the Essentials of Government are prescribed, Instituted, and Constituted in the Word: so there are divers circumstances which are to bee ordered by the generall Rules in the Word, the particular Cases must be Referred to Christian prudence. Wee have in this Covenant many motives set before our eyes; The glory of God, the advancement of Christs Kingdome, the honour and happinesse of the Kings Majesty and his Posterity, the due publike Liberty, safety and Peace of the Kingdomes. The glory of God which is first named is the last and utmost end, the rest are but subordinate ends, or rather meanes to procure that last end: Come then, agree for shame, if the glory of God doe not move thee, thou den iest thy selfe to be a creature, for thou art not moved with that which was the end of thy creation, the glory of God; if the advancement of Christs Kingdom doth not move thee, thou denyest thy selfe to bee a Christian; if the honour and happinesse of the King and his Posterity doth not move thee, thou denyest thy selfe to bee a Subject; if publike liberty doth not invite thee, thou art a slave; if safety doth not perswade thee, thou art desperate; if peace cannot charme thee, thou art Implacable. Come then, you that have any Faith in God, any love to God, any zeale for God, any loyalty to your King, any naturall affection to your Countrey, any charity for Ireland, Scotland, &c.
any Prudence and Providence for Posterity, any sense of Religion, any beliefe that there is a God, and that there will bee a day of Iudgement, I beseech you, I beseech you, as you will answer it at that day, deale honestly with the Searcher of hearts, and expresse your sincerity, zeale, and constancy, in making, and in keeping this Covenant with the Lord of Hoasts.
